#Text=Walter Patterson ( governor )
#Text=For other people named Walter Patterson , see Walter Patterson ( disambiguation ) .
#Text=Walter Patterson ( 1735 or 1742 – 6 September 1798 ) was the first British colonial Governor of Prince Edward Island .
#Text=Birth and life in the military
#Text=The son of William Patterson of Foxhall , near Ramelton , County Donegal , and Elizabeth , daughter of William Thornton Todd of Buncrana Castle , Co. Donegal .
#Text=He was a first cousin of Isaac Todd .
#Text=Patterson joined the British Army early in life , participating in the Seven Years ' War with the 80th Regiment of Light-Armed Foot .
#Text=He was soon appointed to the rank of Captain .
#Text=Governor
#Text=In 1763 , Prince Edward Island ( then known as St. John 's Island ) was ceded to the British by the French , and it became a British colony .

#Text=In 1764 , Patterson requested grants to own land on the island , and he and his brother , John Patterson ( father of future US Naval hero Commodore Daniel Patterson ) , were awarded Lot 19 , near the present-day town of Kensington , through the 1767 land lottery .
#Text=On 30 May 1769 , the British Privy Council declared St. John 's Island a colony with its own government , separating it from Nova Scotia .
#Text=Patterson was appointed the island 's first Governor on 19 July 1769 and arrived on the island on 30 August 1770 .

#Text=Soon after taking the Oath of Office in September 1770 , Patterson had already formed an Executive Council , and one of his and the council 's first ordinances was to enforce the payment of Quit-Rent .
#Text=Following the first Assembly elections in 1773 , Patterson acquired over 100,000 acres ( 400km2 ) of land from proprietors who had failed to pay their quit-rent .
#Text=The land was to be sold off .
#Text=The former proprietors wrote to the British government asking that their land be returned , and when this failed , they asked that Patterson be removed from office .
#Text=This was to the first of several incidents which would cause tension between the British government and Governor Patterson .

#Text=Soon after the petitions were sorted through in England , the Secretary of State from the British government wrote to Patterson , on 24 July 1783 , ordering him to present a bill to the Assembly , one which Patterson was told he had to support .
#Text=The bill was for the annulment of the land sales .
#Text=Going against the British government , Patterson opposed the bill and managed to receive a majority from the Executive Council , supporting his decision .
#Text=The British government retaliated by removing Walter Patterson from office , on 17 June 1786 .
#Text=He officially left office on 4 November .
#Text=In 1789 , Patterson returned to England where he died nine years later .
#Text=The issue of absentee landowners and quit-rent in Prince Edward Island would not be resolved until the passage of the Land Purchase Act in 1875 .
#Text=Spouse
#Text=Walter Patterson was married to Hester Warren in 1770 .
#Text=Unhappy on St. John 's Island , she returned to England in 1771 .
#Text=They had two children , John and Charlotte .
#Text=Walter Patterson 's had two additional children on St. John 's Island with companion Margaret Hyde .
#Text=The Hyde family ( Thomas Hyde , his two sons and four daughters ) arrived in Canada from England in 1770 , on the same boat as Governor Patterson .
